column1: Fulldome refers to immersive dome-based video projection environments. The dome
column3: is filled with real-time (interactive) or pre-rendered (linear) computer animations
column5: or composited environments.Although the current technology emerged in the early-to-mid 1990s
column6: fulldome environments have evolved from numerous influences
column8: with technological roots in domed architecture
column12: and virtual reality.Initial approaches to moving fulldome imagery used wide-angle lenses
column14: but the expense and ungainly nature of the film medium prevented much progress; furthermore
column15: film formats such as Omnimax did not cover the full two pi steradians of the dome surface
column16: leaving a section of the dome blank (though
column18: that part of the dome was not seen by most viewers). Later approaches to fulldome utilized monochromatic vector graphics systems projected through a fisheye lens. Contemporary configurations employ raster video projectors
column19: either singly or grouped together to cover the dome surface with full-color images and animations.
